results.title: The Reflecting pool: collected work 1977-80
results.creator_credit: Artists' Television Workshop at WXXI/TV, Rochester, TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen, Carol Brandenburg, Carvin Eison and Bill Viola
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Viola describes The Reflecting Pool as ‘a collection of five independent works which, taken as a whole, describe the stages of a personal journey using images of transition — from day to night, motion to stillness, time to timelessness, etc. Each work explores specific video techniques and technologies, in combination with the spatial potentials of stereo sound.’ In the title work, all movement and change in an otherwise still scene is confined to the reflections on the surface of a pool in the woods. Suspended in time, a man hovers in a frozen, midair leap over the water, as subtle techniques of still-framing and multiple keying join disparate layers of time into a single coherent image. Viola writes that ‘the piece concerns the emergence of the individual into the natural world — a kind of baptism.’ He describes Moonblood as an expression of the feminine principle, a work in three parts relating to a personal concept of woman and mother. Day and night converge within the silhouette of a woman at a window — a rushing waterfall in winter, and the serene interplay of changing dawn light unfolds within a glass of water at dawn in the desert.’ Silent Life’ records the first hours and days of life through a series of portraits of newborn babies in a hospital nursery. The alienating hospital environment, and the vulnerability of the babies’ pre-lingual gestures and expressions, suggests a primal linking of birth and death. Ancient of Days is a remarkable series ofcanons and fugues for video’ that comprises Viola’s most sophisticated structural and metaphorical explorations of time. Mathematical notations of precise time-code editing were applied to construct illustrations of temporal symmetry, duality and transposition — time-based equivalents of musical compositional principles such as counterpoint and serialism. Astonishing temporal interventions — a 180-degree pan gazing downward on a New York City street that progresses from day to night, an image of Mount Rainier in which the foreground and background unfold in different time planes — unfold as symbolic transformations of natural and urban landscapes. The title of Vegetable Memory derives from the writings of Jalaludin Rumi, 13th-century Persian poet. Evolving as what he terms a ‘kind of temporal magnifying glass,’ the tape explores the perceptual phenomenon of repetitive, cyclic viewing. A loop of images recorded at the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo is extended in progressively slower cycles, changing the form, feeling and ultimately the meaning of the original images as they move further into the subjective and pictorial.

results.title: The Refiners fire
results.creator_credit: C Hemenway, R. Grossman, K Beasley, Doubleday Multi Media and Entropy
results.brief_description: A film produced by high school students, employing animated squares and circles depicting a situation in which a person with new ideas, may influence some, but is often persecuted by the majority. Provides a discussion point on leadership, resistance to change and group dynamics.

results.title: The Referee
results.creator_credit: Robert King, Football Association and Kay Laboratories
results.brief_description: How Association Football referees are selected and trained by the County Associations and the Referees Societies of Britain. The duties and essential qualities of a referee are explained and examples of situations during actual play which call for arbitration are shown.

results.title: The Reefkeepers
results.creator_credit: Robert Alcock, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Shows the life and work of officers and crew aboard the ship, Cape Moreton, as they maintain shipping beacons and lighthouses in the tropics around Torres Strait. Examines the role of the Australian Lighthouse Service.

results.title: The Reef at Michaelmas Cay
results.creator_credit: Douglas B. Steen and Douglas Steen Productions
results.brief_description: Shows a party of divers exploring marine life at Michaelmas Cay, a Great Barrier Reef island near Cairns. Includes scenes of giant clams, razor fish, stone fish, butterfly cod, moray eels, and green turtles.

results.title: The Redwoods
results.creator_credit: Trevor Greenwood, Mark Harris and King Screen Productions
results.brief_description: Sequoia Semperivirens, the giant everlasting redwood, is a link with the age of the dinosaurs. But the future of these trees is threatened. This film, a tribute to nature’s awesome power to create, is also a testament of man’s reckless power to destroy, and it pleads for the establishment of a Redwood National Park in the United States. Narrated by William Turner and Keith Griggs.

results.title: The Redman and the child
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and American Mutoscope and Biograph Company
results.brief_description: A noble Sioux avenges the murder of an old white man who had been his friend. Based on the novel by Bret Harte. Cast includes Charles Inslee, John Tansey, Linda Arvidson, George Gebhardt, Harry Solter. Silent film with no intertitles.

results.title: The Red violin = Le Violon rouge = Violino rosso, Il
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman, Mikado Film Srl (Rome), Sidecar Films and TV and Red Violin Productions
results.brief_description: A five part tale which tells the life story of an exquisite 300 year old violin. The film begins with the loving creation of the instrument in 17th century in Italy by a master craftsman for his unborn child. However, upon the death of the baby the instrument maker curses the violin by adding a secret ingredient to the varnish. The central focus is at an auction house in Montreal where the legendary violin is for sale and the bidding is fierce. The focus of the film is not so much the violin’s future, but its affect on the five lives of those who played it over the years, as we are drawn back into each of their worlds. Coveted by child prodigies, virtuosos and gypsies, the instrument is a poisoned chalice with most of the people who play it meeting a tragic and untimely end. This ambitious film is shot in Cremona, Vienna, Oxford, Shanghai and Montreal, with dialogue in French, English, Italian, Spanish and Mandarin. An Academy Award winning musical soundtrack composed by John Corigliano reminds us of the beauty of the violin as the viewer follows its travels across time and space. Written by Don McKellar and Francois Girard.
